title: SM U-67
text:
SM "U-67 was a <a href="German%20Type%20U%2066%20submarine">Type U 66</a> <a href="submarine">submarine</a> or <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> for the <a href="German%20Imperial%20Navy">German Imperial Navy</a> () during the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>. She had been <a href="keel%20laying">laid down</a> in November 1913 as U-8" the second boat of the <a href="U-7%20class%20submarine%20%28Austria-Hungary%29">"U-7" class</a> for the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Navy">Austro-Hungarian Navy</a> () but was sold to Germany, along with the others in her class, in November 1914.
The submarine was ordered as "U-8" from <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> of <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a> as the second of five boats of the "U-7" class for the Austro-Hungarian Navy. After the outbreak of World War I in August 1914, the Austro-Hungarian Navy became convinced that none of the submarines of the class could be delivered to the <a href="Adriatic">Adriatic</a> via <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>. As a consequence, the entire class, including "U-8", was sold to the German Imperial Navy in November 1914. Under German control, the class became known as the "U 66" type and the boats were renumbered; "U-8" became "U-67", and all were redesigned and reconstructed to German specifications. "U-67" was <a href="launch%20%28ship%29">launch</a>ed in May 1915 and <a href="commission%20%28ship%29">commission</a>ed in August. As completed, she displaced , surfaced, and , submerged. The boat was long and was armed with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s and a <a href="deck%20gun">deck gun</a>.
A part of the IV Flotilla throughout the war, "U-67" sank 17 ships with a combined <a href="gross%20register%20tonnage">gross register tonnage</a> (GRT) of 39,720 in thirteen war patrols. She also damaged four other ships of . On 20 November 1918, nine days after the <a href="Armistice%20with%20Germany">Armistice</a>, "U-67" was surrendered to the British. She was broken up in 1921 at <a href="Fareham">Fareham</a>.
Design and construction.
After the Austro-Hungarian Navy had competitively evaluated three foreign submarine designs, it selected the <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> 506d design, also known as the Type UD, for its new "U-7" class of five submarines. The Navy ordered five boats on 1 February 1913.
The "U-7" class was seen by the Austro-Hungarian Navy as an improved version of its <a href="U-3%20class%20submarine%20%28Austria-Hungary%29">"U-3" class</a>, which was also a Germaniawerft design. As designed for the Austro-Hungarian Navy, the boats were to <a href="displace%20%28ship%29">displace</a> on the surface and while submerged. The <a href="hull%20%28submarine%29">doubled-hulled</a> boats were to be <a href="length%20overall">long overall</a> with a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of and a <a href="draft%20%28hull%29">draft</a> of . The Austrian specifications called for two shafts with twin <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s ( total) for surface running at up to , and twin <a href="electric%20motor">electric motor</a>s ( total) for a maximum of when submerged. The boats were designed with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s; four located in the bow, one in the stern. The boats' armament was to also include a single L/26 deck gun.
"U-8" and <a href="sister%20boat">sister boat</a> were both <a href="keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 1 November 1913, the first two boats of the class begun. Her construction was slated to be complete within 29 to 33 months.
Neither "U-8" nor any of her <a href="sister%20boat">sister boat</a>s were complete when World War I began in August 1914. With the boats under construction at <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a>, the Austrians became convinced that it would be impossible to take delivery of the boats, which would need to be towed into the Mediterranean past <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>, a British territory. As a result, "U-8" and her four sisters were sold to the <a href="Imperial%20German%20Navy">Imperial German Navy</a> on 28 November 1914.
"U-8" was renumbered by the Germans as "U-67" when her class was redesignated as the Type U 66. The Imperial German Navy had the submarines redesigned and reconstructed to German standards, which increased the surface displacement by and the submerged by . The torpedo load was increased by a third, from 9 to 12, and the deck gun was upgraded from the gun originally specified to an <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20L/30%20naval%20gun">Uk L/30</a> one.
Service career.
"U-67" was <a href="launch%20%28ship%29">launch</a>ed on 15 May 1915. On 4 August, SM "U-67" was <a href="commission%20%28ship%29">commission</a>ed into the <a href="Imperial%20German%20Navy">Imperial German Navy</a> under the command of "<a href="Korvettenkapit%C3%A4n">Korvettenkapitän</a>" Erich von Rosenberg-Grusczyski. On 28 October 1915, "U-67" was assigned to the <a href="IV%20Flottille">IV. "U-Halbflotille"</a> in which she remained for the duration of the war.
In March 1916, <a href="Kapit%C3%A4nleutnant">Kapitänleutnant</a> Hans Nieland replaced von Rosenberg-Grusczyski as the captain of "U-67", and it was under his command that "U-67" was most successful, sinking 17 ships with a combined a total of , while damaging a further four of 19,048 GRT. "U-67"s most successful month was April 1917, when she sank four ships of 15,223 GRT in a span of twelve days.
Nieland was succeeded as commander of "U-67" by <a href="Oberleutnant%20zur%20See">Oberleutnant zur See</a> Helmuth von Rabenau in December 1917. Under his command during the last eleven months of the war, "U-67" sank no more ships. During her service career under three commanders, "U-67" had completed thirteen war patrols. She was surrendered to the British on 20 November 1918, nine days after the <a href="Armistice%20with%20Germany">Armistice</a>, and broken up at <a href="Fareham">Fareham</a> in 1921.
